title: L&F Shares Fall After Writing Down Value of Tesla Contract - Morningstar
description:
By Kwanwoo Jun L&F's shares slumped early Tuesday after the South Korean battery-material maker sharply reduced the value of its previous contract with electric-vehicle giant Tesla.
Under the deal, L&F had agreed to supply high-nickel cathode materials to Tesla and its affiliates from early 2024 through late 2025.
Earlier this month, South Korean battery maker LG Energy Solution said that its previous multibillion-dollar contracts with Ford Motor and Freudenberg Battery Power Systems had been canceled.
Another Korean battery supplier, SK On, also said it had ended its joint venture with Ford in the U.S. this month.
Write to Kwanwoo Jun at kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com (END) Dow Jones Newswires December 29, 2025 20:04 ET (01:04 GMT) Copyright (c) 2025 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
text:
By Kwanwoo Jun

L&F's shares slumped early Tuesday after the South Korean battery-material maker sharply reduced the value of its previous contract with electric-vehicle giant Tesla.

The company's stock fell as much as 12% to 92,700 won, equivalent to $64.57, in Seoul trading, on course for its sharpest daily decline in two months. The benchmark Kospi was last down 0.5%.

L&F said after Monday's market close that the value of a 2023 multiyear contract with Tesla had shrunk to just $7,386 from $2.91 billion due to a change in supply volume.

Under the deal, L&F had agreed to supply high-nickel cathode materials to Tesla and its affiliates from early 2024 through late 2025.

L&F's drastic write-down of the deal value occurred amid Tesla's slower-than-expected sales of Cybertruck EVs and its struggles to boost EV battery production after the Trump administration ended U.S. tax credits for new EV purchases.

South Korea's battery sector has been hurt by sluggish demand from EV makers and battery cell manufacturers.

Earlier this month, South Korean battery maker LG Energy Solution said that its previous multibillion-dollar contracts with Ford Motor and Freudenberg Battery Power Systems had been canceled.

Another Korean battery supplier, SK On, also said it had ended its joint venture with Ford in the U.S. this month.

Write to Kwanwoo Jun at kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

December 29, 2025 20:04 ET (01:04 GMT)

title: As 2025 ends, Colorado officially falls short of its first major greenhouse gas target
description:
Still, Colorado’s top energy official said he was “pleasantly surprised” by the findings of the state’s latest comprehensive emissions report.
Released this month, the biennial report, known as a greenhouse gas inventory, is the first to estimate the effects of the recent federal rollbacks on Colorado’s climate action plan.
“In terms of our GHG emissions trajectory, the impact is not as large as I feared it might be,” Will Toor, executive director of the Colorado Energy Office, said in an interview.
Its trajectory towards the next target, a 50 percent cut by 2030, is similarly about two years behind schedule, at least for now.
While the rate of growth has slowed, annual carbon emissions have continued to rise globally, reaching another all-time high in 2024.
text:
When Colorado Democrats took full control of state government nearly seven years ago, one of the party’s top priorities in the General Assembly was the passage of a climate action plan that would commit the state to the ambitious cuts to greenhouse gas emissions recommended by climate scientists.

House Bill 19-1261, signed by Governor Jared Polis in 2019, marked the first time Colorado had codified greenhouse gas targets in state law — and the end of calendar year 2025 is the deadline to meet the first of the goals, a 26 percent reduction in statewide emissions compared to 2005 levels.

Colorado will fall short of that goal.

That outcome has been all but certain for the last few years, as the state struggled to achieve the needed cuts, especially when it came to vehicle emissions, and state officials have previously acknowledged their efforts to meet the 2025 goal were at least a year behind schedule. The target slipped further out of reach this year as President Donald Trump’s administration and Republicans in Congress rolled back an array of clean energy incentives, including tax credits for electric cars and home heating upgrades.

Still, Colorado’s top energy official said he was “pleasantly surprised” by the findings of the state’s latest comprehensive emissions report. Released this month, the biennial report, known as a greenhouse gas inventory, is the first to estimate the effects of the recent federal rollbacks on Colorado’s climate action plan.

“In terms of our GHG emissions trajectory, the impact is not as large as I feared it might be,” Will Toor, executive director of the Colorado Energy Office, said in an interview. “What the latest inventory shows is that it basically pushes us back (another) year.”

That means the state now expects to meet its 2025 target — about 103 million tons of carbon emissions, a 26 percent cut from about 140 million tons two decades ago — in 2027. Its trajectory towards the next target, a 50 percent cut by 2030, is similarly about two years behind schedule, at least for now.

“There’s a lot of uncertainty about what the federal government is going to do in the future,” Toor cautioned. “There is a lot more work that we’re going to need to do to make sure that we are accurately capturing the effects of all of the attacks on clean energy … from the Trump administration.”

Colorado’s approach

Climate scientists have warned that to avert the most catastrophic impacts of global warming, governments around the world must cut greenhouse gas emissions in half by 2030 and reach net-zero emissions by midcentury.

The world is badly off track to meet those targets. While the rate of growth has slowed, annual carbon emissions have continued to rise globally, reaching another all-time high in 2024.

Colorado’s emissions peaked around 2010 and had declined by about 16 percent from 2005 levels as of 2023, the latest year for which historical estimates are available, according to the new inventory.

Polis’ administration has embraced what it describes as a “whole-of-government approach” to climate action, pursuing a wide range of policies across different emissions sectors and regulatory bodies, including the Public Utilities Commission, the Department of Transportation, the Air Quality Control Commission and the Energy and Carbon Management Commission.

That approach hasn’t been without its critics among climate and environmental advocates, who warned as early as 2020that the state wasn’t doing enough to meet its 2025 and 2030 goals. Advocates have been repeatedly left frustrated by the scope and ambition of the Polis administration’s climate regulations, especially at the AQCC.

U.S. Senator Michael Bennet, a Democratic candidate for governor in 2026, on Dec. 9 announced a climate plan centered on a “cap-and-invest” program, reviving a proposal that some influential advocacy groups had hoped to enact through the AQCC after HB-1261’s passage seven years ago.

A separate report released this month by a coalition of Colorado environmental groups emphasized the need for the state to make “strategic near-term capital investments” to get back on track with its emissions goals.

“Coloradans see the impacts of climate change firsthand, in the form of more intense drought, more frequent wildfires and longer hotter summers,” Stacy Tellinghuisen, deputy director of policy development with Western Resource Advocates, said in a briefing on the new report. “Those impacts translate into real costs, but taking action — enacting forward looking policies to address climate pollution — has benefits for equity, for affordability and for air quality.”

name: Detroit Environment
title: Michigan loses funding in climate-related investments, green manufacturing projects
description:
$20 million for the Inter-Tribal Council of Michigan toimprove energy efficiency in tribal homes 4.
Michigan saw $3 billion worth of disinvestment this year as companies scrapped planned EV factories or closed existing ones, according to the Atlas analysis.
Timelines and ambitions for numerous other EV and battery factory projects in Michigan have shifted amid the changing policies and market forces.
GM, for instance, sold its stake in a planned EV battery factory near Lansing to LG Energy Solution and the plant's planned opening has been delayed from 2025 to 2026.
And Ford has scaled back plans for an EV battery plant near Marshall, now slated to open in 2026.
text:
At this time in 2024, Michigan was expecting a windfall of federal funds to fuel a transition to clean energy, along with billions of dollars' worth of green manufacturing projects subsidized by the Biden administration's signature climate spending bills.

But since President Donald Trump began his second term in January and began scrapping federal climate programs he refers to collectively as "the green new scam," Michigan has seen a wave of project and grant cancellations, along with renewed investment in fossil fuel-based manufacturing and power generation.

Roughly $540 million in climate-related grants to Michigan have been canceled or held up since Inauguration Day, according to a national database compiled by Atlas Public Policy, while shifting market forces and the end of federal tax credits for electric vehicles have caused clean manufacturing investments in Michigan to whipsaw from billions annually in recent years to $3 billion in canceled investments this year.

"It certainly mirrors what we're seeing nationally," said Annabelle Rosser, a research analyst with the national firm.

Instead, Michigan automakers are scaling back and refocusing on gas and hybrid vehicle production — a trend emblemized by Ford's and General Motors' recent decisions to scrap EV production plans at Michigan plants and retool to produce gas-powered vehicles.

"That's just the way the market is shaking out right now," said Glenn Stevens, executive director of MichAuto, an affiliate of the Detroit Regional Chamber.

It's a trend likely to continue into 2026, as Trump administration officials continue their efforts to downplay climate change, deemphasize renewable energy and embrace fossil fuels.

Here's where things stand in Michigan as the year draws to a close:

Michigan has seen $540 million in canceled funding, with the biggest chunk coming from the Solar for All Program, a $7 billion US Environmental Protection Agency fund meant to expand solar energy in disadvantaged communities.

Michigan had been slated to receive a $156 million grant through that fund, while Native American tribes in the state were expecting part of a $62 million grant shared with other Great Lakes tribes.

Michigan Attorney General Dana Nessel has sued over the grant cancellations, joining 22 other states to argue the administration "unilaterally and illegally terminated" the program, overstepping checks and balances to cancel congressionally approved funding.

Beyond the solar program, the federal government has canceled or proposed to cancel more than 20 Michigan grants ranging from $31.7 million to help LuxWall Inc. build an energy-efficient window glass factory in Detroit to $14,000 for a west Michigan climate resilience project.

Other canceled grants include:

1. $28.2 million for TS Conductor to build a high-capacity power line plant in Erie

2. $20.4 million for Ecoworks, a Detroit nonprofit that planned to convert houses of worship into climate resilience hubs

3. $20 million for the Inter-Tribal Council of Michigan toimprove energy efficiency in tribal homes

4. $20 million for the Southwestern Michigan Planning Commission to build two resilience hubs in Benton Harbor, upgrade energy efficiency in low-income housing and support a workforce development initiative

Smaller grants would have funded energy efficient housing in Kalamazoo, a climate change and resilience plan for the city of Flint and wild rice bed restoration in Michigan waterways.

The Trump administration has also frozen a $20 billion federal "green bank" network that had been expected to send hundreds of millions of dollars to Michigan to build and rehab housing across the state, insulate old homes and boost energy efficiency in factories.

Trump officials have signaled that more cancellations could be coming as they review tens of billions of dollars in clean energy funds awarded by the previous administration.

Michigan utilities, for example, are awaiting word on the status of $15 billion in clean energy-related loans announced days before Trump took office. And the Trump administration is reevaluating a grant program that awarded $500 million to retool a Lansing GM factory for electrified vehicles.

An exception to the administration's shift of resources away from Biden-era energy policies: It has continued making disbursements from a $1.5 billion loan authorized in 2024 to support the reopening of the Palisades nuclear power plant and in December announced another $400 million to develop two new reactors at the site.

"President Trump has made clear that America is going to build more energy, not less, and nuclear is central to that mission," US Secretary of Energy Chris Wright said in a statement accompanying the grant announcement.

Spurred along by federal and state subsidies and regulations that encouraged automakers to build EVs and consumers to buy them, Michigan manufacturers announced a collective $23.8 billion in new investments tied to the energy transition between 2022 and 2024, mostly related to battery or EV plants.

Fast-forward to 2025, and the trendline has reversed. Michigan saw $3 billion worth of disinvestment this year as companies scrapped planned EV factories or closed existing ones, according to the Atlas analysis.

Spokespeople for the US Department of Energy, which has overseen efforts to reprioritize fossil fuels by shifting federal resources and loosening vehicle emissions regulations, did not respond to requests for comment from Bridge Michigan.

But Trump has routinely cast EVs as a costly "scam" while downplaying the effects of climate change caused by burning fossil fuels like gasoline. During a December announcement that his administration would loosen fuel economy standards applying to new vehicles, Trump cast his pro-gas policies as a win for consumers that would "protect American jobs" and shave "at least $1,000 off the price of a new car."

The biggest EV-related cancellation is the Gotion project, a once-planned $2.4 billion electric vehicle battery plant near Big Rapids that spent years embroiled in controversy before state officials declared the project dead this fall.

In that case, Rosser, the Atlas analyst, said, shifting federal policies weren't the only factor.

"The rollback of the (Inflation Reduction Act) clean energy tax credits, softening demand for electric vehicles, and concerns about the company's foreign ownership are all likely factors," Rosser said.

This fall, battery maker XALT Energy announced plans to close its Midland headquarters and an Auburn Hills facility just two years after announcing plans to spend a "double digit million sum" expanding the facility.

Automotive supplier Dana Inc., which had vowed to invest $54.2 million at an Auburn Hills EV battery plant by the end of 2024, instead announced this fall that it would close the plant amid an "unexpected and immediate reduction in customer orders driven by lower demand for electric vehicles."

Fortescue canceled an under-construction $210 million EV charger, battery and hydrogen generator plant at the former Fisher Body site in Detroit, citing shifting US markets and policies including the loss of "critical tax credits."

Other losses included the closure of an Akasol electric vehicle battery factory in Warren and canceled plans to build a TS Conductor high-voltage direct current conductor plant in Erie using a since-canceled $28 million federal grant.

TS Conductor is still building the plant, but switched locations to South Carolina after receiving what company CEO Jason Huang described as a "very generous incentive package."

Timelines and ambitions for numerous other EV and battery factory projects in Michigan have shifted amid the changing policies and market forces. GM, for instance, sold its stake in a planned EV battery factory near Lansing to LG Energy Solution and the plant's planned opening has been delayed from 2025 to 2026. And Ford has scaled back plans for an EV battery plant near Marshall, now slated to open in 2026.

Stevens said he expects the EV market to grow in 2026, but "it's not going to be at the acceleration curve that a lot of people projected, and certainly the previous administration was pushing."

title: U.S. Natural Gas Prices Jump on Storage Draw and Record LNG Feedgas
description:
U.S. natural gas futures climbed to a three-week high after a storage draw in line with forecasts, colder weather outlooks and record LNG feedgas flows boosted demand expectations.
(Reuters) — U.S. natural gas futures extended gains on Dec. 29 to hit a three-week high, after federal data showed storage levels in line with forecasts, as colder weather outlooks and record liquefied natural gas export flows boosted demand expectations.
The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) said energy firms pulled 166 billion cubic feet (Bcf) of gas out of storage during the week ended Dec. 19.
Financial firm LSEG projected average gas demand in the lower 48 states, including exports, would fall slightly from 138.4 billion cubic feet per day this week to 135.8 billion cubic feet per day over the next week.
LSEG said average natural gas output in the lower 48 U.S. states climbed to a record high of 110.1 billion cubic feet per day in December, surpassing November's monthly record of 109.6 billion cubic feet per day.
text:
U.S. natural gas futures climbed to a three-week high after a storage draw in line with forecasts, colder weather outlooks and record LNG feedgas flows boosted demand expectations.

(Reuters) — U.S. natural gas futures extended gains on Dec. 29 to hit a three-week high, after federal data showed storage levels in line with forecasts, as colder weather outlooks and record liquefied natural gas export flows boosted demand expectations.

Front-month gas futures for January delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose 6.7%, to $4.65 per million British thermal units, as of 12:32 PM ET, after hitting its highest level since December 10 earlier in the session.

Gas futures for February, which will soon be the front-month, were up about 3.1% to around $3.99 per MMBtu.

The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) said energy firms pulled 166 billion cubic feet (Bcf) of gas out of storage during the week ended Dec. 19.

That was in line with the 168-bcf withdrawal analysts forecast in a Reuters poll and compares with a decline of 98 Bcf during the same week last year and an average withdrawal of 110 Bcf over the past five years (2020-2024).

"There is overall demand and if we continue to get cold weather, we could see those inventories drop even further. I think it's also reflective of the fact that we're getting cold weather and we're seeing record demand for exports," said Phil Flynn, senior analyst for Price Futures Group.

Meteorologists forecast a slight drop in temperatures nationwide through January 12, with Heating Degree Days rising from 398 on Friday to 412 on Monday, exceeding the near-normal level of 394.

Adding to bullish sentiment, average gas flows to the eight large U.S. liquefied natural gas export plants have risen to 18.5 billion cubic feet per day so far this month, up from a monthly record high of 18.2 billion cubic feet per day in November.

On a daily basis, LNG feedgas was set to reach a three-week high of 18.8 billion cubic feet per day on Monday driven primarily by increased flows to Cheniere Energy's 4.5-billion cubic feet per day Sabine Pass plant in Louisiana, which rose to about 5.1 billion cubic feet per day from an average of 4.9 billion cubic feet per day over the prior seven days, according to LSEG data.

Financial firm LSEG projected average gas demand in the lower 48 states, including exports, would fall slightly from 138.4 billion cubic feet per day this week to 135.8 billion cubic feet per day over the next week. The forecast for this week was higher than LSEG's outlook on Friday.

LSEG said average natural gas output in the lower 48 U.S. states climbed to a record high of 110.1 billion cubic feet per day in December, surpassing November's monthly record of 109.6 billion cubic feet per day.

"Production continues to be strong. If the cold weather doesn't impact production, then prices will stabilize. But if this cold weather settles in for a while, then it looks like we could push prices back above $4 for the February contract," Flynn said.

Dutch and British gas prices rose, with the European benchmark contract hitting a one-month high after the holiday break, driven by strong demand because of cold weather.

text:
The electric vehicle industry has taken a pummeling this year. The Trump administration, as expected, reversed a whole suite of federal policies that promoted or encouraged EVs.

California's ability to require the sale of EVs: gone. Federal rules about emissions and fuel economy — being rewritten. Federal penalties for car companies that sell too many gas guzzlers: zeroed out. The $7,500 federal tax credit? Kaput.

Meanwhile, automakers delayed or canceled a host of unprofitable EV plans.

The all-electric Ram 1500 REV was canceled before a single one was built. The all-electric Ford Lightning was discontinued despite some glowing reviews. (Both pickups will be replaced with extended-range electric vehicles, which come with both a big battery and a backup gas tank.)

The buzzy Volkswagen Buzz is still available in other countries, but no longer in the U.S. The GM Brightdrop van is no more. The list goes on.

As for sales? "It's a roller-coaster ride," says Stephanie Valdez Streaty, who monitors EVs for the data and services company Cox Automotive.

Sales spiked in August and September, during the last weeks that the federal tax credit was available, as buyers rushed to take advantage of the expiring opportunity. Cox estimated EVs hit an all-time high of 11.6% of the new vehicle market in September. Then sales crashed by 50% in October.

But here's a twist.

"Among U.S. shoppers who are in [the] market for new vehicles, the interest in electric vehicles actually ticked up a bit after the tax credit went away," says Brent Gruber, who runs the EV practice at consumer insights company J.D. Power.

It's the EV story you might not have heard this year: Despite the political and product planning whiplash, consumer appetite for EVs has been on a very smooth ride.

Overall, about 25% of new car shoppers are very interested in buying an EV, according to J.D. Power surveys. And with minor fluctuations, "it's held pretty consistent," Gruber says, despite what he calls the "turbulence" of this year.

"There's still a tremendous amount of interest," he says. "And from an EV owner perspective, we continue to see high levels of satisfaction once people do get into those products." In fact, EV owners are 94% likely to repurchase another EV for their next vehicle, he says.

BJ Birtwell runs the Electrify Expo, a traveling festival dedicated to EVs. He says EVs have suffered from being politicized, with a lot of right-of-center Americans rejecting them out of hand.

"There's still a cloud of skepticism around EVs across some parts of the country," he says. But put a skeptic behind the wheel of a new EV, he says, "and I'll tell you what I see: Smiles for miles." Test drives reveal the cars are fun to drive, he says, and a little research can show that charging at home is easier and cheaper than they thought.

An American slowdown

Still, while Americans remain interested in EVs, it's undeniable that battery-powered vehicles are taking off more slowly than industry execs expected a few years ago. That's not just because of the policy reversal; it's also because of market realities. For example, while charging might be easy at home, it's a hassle for apartment dwellers who don't have that option. Meanwhile, vehicle prices — a challenge for the entire auto market — are even higher for EVs. Lower fuel and maintenance costs can't always overcome that up-front sticker shock, even for people who are hypothetically interested in buying.

This slowdown will have global consequences for the environment and for human beings: It locks in higher carbon emissions and air pollution for years to come.

The legacy automakers, of course, have lost billions of dollars on the EV designs they've canceled or postponed. But the delay hurts more than just the big-name auto brands. A whole network of suppliers sell parts to the automakers, and they also bear the burden when plans change.

Ken O'Trakoun of RPM Partners works with auto suppliers in distress. "The whiplash," he says, "between demand going up and demand receding, it has impacted a number of suppliers." They made investments in factories to supply automakers for vehicles that either aren't being made, or are being made at much lower volumes. "It's pretty disruptive."

The "ripple effect" from those suppliers "creates impacts on jobs," Valdez-Streaty notes.

Automakers, too, have laid off or reassigned employees away from battery plants and EV production lines as part of their adjusted timelines.

A clear global trend

But while automakers are slowing their EV plans down significantly, they're not giving up on them, either.

Partly that's because of the enduring consumer interest; as long as there's a market, the automakers want to serve it. And partly that's because the automakers are all global companies. They want to be able to sell to the rest of the world, too.

"On a global scale, internal combustion engine cars already peaked back, like, eight or nine years ago," says Huiling Zhou, U.S. EV analyst for the research group BloombergNEF.

About one in four cars sold worldwide this year was electric, Zhou says — driven by China's remarkably fast embrace of those vehicles. And China, increasingly, is exporting cars around the world.

That means that the global market for cars that run on gas or diesel is shrinking, while the market for battery-powered cars is expanding — and China is dominating it.

If automakers want to compete around the world, they simply can't afford to get off the EV roller coaster.

The Rose Parade is right around the corner, and thousands of people are already preparing to flock to Pasadena for the New Year’s Day festivities.

In its 137th year, the parade theme is “The Magic in Teamwork,” with Laker icon Earvin "Magic" Johnson as the Grand Marshal. It kicks off at 8 a.m.

Whether you’ll be camping out the night before, or heading over with blankets in tow in the early morning hours, keep in mind that the weather is currently forecast to be rainy. Yes, that's rare. If it does pour on the parade it will be the first time in 20 years and before that it had been 50 years since the last rainy parade day.

Here’s what you need to know this year.

Parade details and closures

The Rose Parade route lasts two hours, with its 5.5-mile journey starting at Green Street and Orange Grove Boulevard.

The floats, bands, and horses will head north along Orange Grove at a slow but steady 2.5 mph pace before turning east onto Colorado Boulevard for a majority of the show. It’ll then head north onto Sierra Madre Boulevard, wrapping up at Villa Street.

Police and city officials will start closing off part of the route to cars as early as 6 p.m. Wednesday, Dec. 31, through 2 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 1.

That includes Colorado Boulevard from Orange Grove Boulevard to Sierra Madre Boulevard, and Sierra Madre Boulevard to Paloma Street. So if you’ll be hosting viewing parties or are overdue for a delivery, Tournament of Roses officials recommend telling everyone to arrive before the closures kick in Wednesday night.

If you’ll need to drive to or through the downtown Pasadena area, you can use:

Walnut Street or the 210 Freeway for east-west travel north of Colorado Boulevard

Del Mar Boulevard or Cordova Street for east-west travel south of Colorado Boulevard

There will be limited crossing for north-south travel during the closure (see map for details)

Please note: There will be a 5K race at midnight to celebrate the New Year from Pasadena Avenue to Hill Street. Several intersections will close to cross traffic at 11 p.m. Dec. 31 and re-open at the end of the race event at about 2 a.m., including Pasadena, Fair Oaks, and Marengo avenues (see full list on map.)

Tickets

You can still snag grandstand tickets — we found ones from $80 to $130, depending on where you want to sit. You’ll need to have your ticket handy.

The parade is scheduled to begin promptly at 8 a.m. Organizers recommend that ticketholders aim to be seated by 7 a.m. In order to do that, you should plan to arrive in the area by at least 6 a.m. to give yourself plenty of time to work through the crowds and traffic.

Note that there is a "clear bags only" policy in place for grandstand seating at the Rose Parade, the Rose Bowl game and several other events. You can find details here.

Curbside seating and camping

Curbside seating is free, and lots of people will set up shop and camp overnight, which is only allowed on Dec. 31. If you’ll be bringing your kids or teens along, they need to be with an adult during the overnight hours.

You can grab your sidewalk spot starting at noon Dec. 31, but all your blankets and chairs have to stay on the curb until 11 p.m., at which point you’ll be able to move up a bit closer to the blue “honor-line.” Tents, sofas, unoccupied chairs, and boxes that can be used as stools or seats are not allowed along the route.

You can warm up with a small elevated barbecue, but it needs to be away from buildings and you have to have a fire extinguisher available. Bonfires and fireworks are banned, period.

Most importantly, don’t forget to drink water and dress for cool temps and the possibility of rain. (You can always sit on that extra jacket).

Given the weather conditions, it's important to note that the rules call for no umbrellas. The City of Pasadena advisers parade goers to use rain jackets and ponchos, which they optimistically describe as "a great alternative so everyone can enjoy the show!"

LAist's Sharon McNary, a longtime Pasadena resident who has offered great tips on making the most of the parade in the past, points out this might be a very popular year for what she calls "The People’s Grandstand.”

That said, Sharon notes "it’s kind of a locals-only institution. Fans create their own little wooden seats that fit nicely into the notches in the stones lining the sloped wall of the 210 Freeway overpass over Sierra Madre Blvd. In the rare rainy year, they have shelter, and in the more typical warm years, they have shade. And they get to view the spectacle of the taller floats folding themselves down to fit under the overpass and opening back up on the other side."

Parking

There is no parking allowed on the parade route, but you can purchase reserved spots. Pasadena recommendations include Sharp Seating, the city itself, and LAZ Parking. Parking at Metro rail stations are another option you can check on before you head out.

Authorities urge that you pay for parking in advance to guarantee your spot. Otherwise, parking is on a first-come, first-served basis and of course that supply is limited.

Once again: Arriving extra early is your best bet so you can avoid the traffic hassles and any unintended GPS glitches. Authorities warn: "Please do not rely upon your GPS as road closures will be in effect and may not reflect on the GPS application."

All parking meters are free and time limits will not be enforced on New Year’s Day, and overnight parking restrictions will not be enforced until 2 a.m. Jan. 4, according to the city. But keep an eye out for red curbs, “No Parking” signs, fire hydrants, and driveways, as the usual restrictions still apply. You don't want to risk getting your vehicle towed.

Public transportation

Where possible, public transit might be your easiest way to go, and Metrolink will be offering special early morning hours on the San Bernardino, Antelope Valley, Orange County, Ventura County, and 91 Perris Valley lines for the parade. (Note that Metrolink’s Riverside County Line is not running on New Year’s Day.)

From the Metro website: "On New Year’s Eve and early New Year’s Day (Dec. 31 to Jan. 1), we’ll be running service all night on the A, B, D and E Lines with additional early morning service to help get you to Pasadena on time for the parade, which begins at 8 a.m. sharp." Metro will also have buses traveling to areas near the route and Rose Bowl game.

You can find more information here.

These are the A Line stations in Pasadena that closest to the parade:

Del Mar Station (walk .3 miles north to the parade route)

Memorial Park Station (walk .2 miles south)

Lake Station (walk .4 miles south)

Allen Station (walk .4 miles south)

Metro will also have buses traveling to areas near the route and Rose Bowl game, which you can find more information on here

Metro is offering free fares on buses, trains, Metro Bike Share and Metro Micro from 4 a.m. Dec. 31 until 3 a.m. Jan. 1. For Metro Bike Share, use code 123125 on New Year’s Eve. For Metro Micro riders, use promo code RING26.

Accessible viewing

Three street-level viewing areas are reserved for people with disabilities and up to four of their guests.

Each of those areas along the parade route will have a section with audio descriptions for visually impaired people and another with sign language interpreters.

Tickets to all these viewing areas are free! But to request space, you’ll need to complete a form. The 2026 form is already marked closed, but for future planning, here is the Jan. 1, 2027 form.

Please note: no seats are provided, so you’ll need to bring your own arrangements.

There’s also limited wheelchair accessible grandstand seating sold through Sharp Seating.

Rose Bowl game

The Rose Bowl game, the oldest of bowls dating back to 1902, immediately follows the parade. The Rose Bowl Stadium parking lot opens at 4 a.m. Jan. 1 and the stadium gates open at 10:30 a.m. The game starts at 1 p.m.

A quick scan turned up tickets that are still available for the Indiana vs. Alabama matchup for a little as $130.90 and as much as $2,683.13.

General parking is available in certain lots at the stadium, with spots going for $69 that you buy it in advance.

For public transportation, you can take the Metro A line and exit at the Memorial Park station. You can find more information here about getting to the stadium.

Please note: the stadium has a clear-bag policy, which means backpacks, purses, and camera cases are not allowed.

If you want more info

If you’re dying for more details, you can download the official Rose Parade app here or here. You’ll be able to see the full line-up, maps, and get more information about the participants.

If you skimmed over the rules and your car gets towed on New Year’s Day, you can call (626) 577-6426 from 5 p.m. Dec. 31 until 6 p.m. Jan. 1.

And if you still have questions that have not been answered here, you can try the visitor hotline at (877) 793-9911.

text:
An Oregon-based solar power company closed down on Dec. 26, blaming cuts from the One Big Beautiful Bill.

A Medford-based solar power company blamed federal cutbacks from the One Big Beautiful Bill Act when it notified the state that it was closing as of Dec. 26 and laying off 109 employees.

Purelight Power CEO JD Beck filed a notification to the state as part of the Worker Adjustment Retraining and Notification Act on Dec. 23.

He said that 84 of the workers were based out of the company’s Medford location and another 25 worked remotely. He said 96 of the employees were laid off on Dec. 23 and the rest were laid off Dec. 26.

Beck said the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, also known as House Resolution 1, cut solar energy tax credits when it was signed into law on July 4.

“Before the enactment of the OBBB, the company had benefited from the Inflation Reduction Act, which had promised to boost federal tax incentives for solar energy for at least a decade,” Beck wrote.

Beck said the OBBB "dramatically cut solar energy tax credits and significantly restricted the use of such credits."

He also said the company had been facing challenges related to a prior merger, rising interest rates and increasing advertising costs.

Purelight Power said that it pursued selling the company and had three offers to buy it, but those weren’t accepted by the company’s lender. That lender placed the company in default.

The company said it is shutting down operations nationwide and will be filing for Chapter 7 liquidation. Purelight also operated in Washington, Idaho, Montana, Minnesota, Iowa, Indiana and Kentucky.

text:
Principal Maddie Boyer (Austin) and Of Counsel Stephen Smith (Washington, DC) recently spoke with Bloomberg Law about the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) “compliance first” Memorandum released earlier this month. B&D analyzed these developments in a recent alert, “Compliance First”: What EPA’s Updated Priorities Mean for Industry.

In “EPA Shift to Prioritize Compliance Seen Easing Enforcement Focus,” Bloomberg Law reports that some environmental groups are concerned that EPA will no longer take action against “bad actors.” Maddie explained that is not the case. “There’s no ‘give industry a pass’ subtext here,” she said, adding that EPA’s “core mission will continue.” B&D’s alert described this, noting that industry should not interpret the Memorandum “as a directive to reduce inspections or reduce enforcement generally.”

Stephen said that the Memorandum “gives regulated entities an additional outlet to elevate their arguments from the regional offices up to EPA headquarters.” He projected that this channel of communication “could promote greater consistency in enforcement actions nationwide.”

B&D anticipated EPA to adopt this orientation, with our Texas office having direct experience with a similar policy implementation when Craig Pritzlaff served as Director of the Office of Compliance and Enforcement at the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.

As we have for 50 years through Democratic and Republican administrations, Beveridge & Diamond stands ready to help our clients respond to shifts in law and policy, to counsel them in state and federal government enforcement matters and internal investigations (including criminal matters), and to defend them in all types of litigation – including toxic torts, class actions, and the new wave of citizen/NGO, plaintiffs’ bar and “blue state” attorney general lawsuits. Nearly two-thirds of B&D lawyers have prior U.S. state or federal government experience, including several former senior EPA and DOJ attorneys who served under both the initial Trump and Biden administrations.

title: Mercury 2025 Recap: Environmental News

text:
Climate and the new City Council

Portland’s new City Council started grappling with the city’s climate issues as soon as councilors took office at the beginning of this year. One of the Council’s first acts of business in January was to establish eight policy committees—including one focused on environmental and land use issues. The Council was able to spotlight some underdiscussed environmental issues—like Portland’s relationship with biofuels and “renewable” natural gas—through this committee, though it’s unclear what, if any, changes will result from such conversations.

Zenith under the microscope

Zenith Energy was another major topic of conversation in Portland this year. Many of the new councilors came into office concerned about Zenith and other fuel companies based at Portland’s Critical Energy Infrastructure (CEI) hub on the Willamette River, which pose environmental risks to the city. Early in the year, former City Administrator Michael Jordan granted Zenith a new Land Use Compatibility Statement (LUCS), allowing the company to continue its operations in compliance with state mandates. The decision came at roughly the same time as several councilors began making moves to investigate Zenith and the city’s dealings with the company, displaying the limits of the new Council’s authority over Portland’s administrative branch.

Fighting for Forest Park

The city also wrestled with Portland General Electric’s (PGE) plan to construct a major utility project in Forest Park. The plan, which would require removing around 400 trees from Portland’s largest park, was hated by many climate advocates, who said PGE didn’t attempt to find alternative solutions before proposing a Forest Park clearcut. After a city hearings officer sided with PGE to greenlight the project, opponents appealed. In the end, Portland City Council unanimously voted against the utility company’s plan—a relatively rare show of unity among councilors who don’t always agree, and a win for tree lovers dubious of PGE’s proposal. (Environmental advocates say it was also a win for species who live in the park, including Northern red-legged frogs. Portland’s frogs—real and inflatable—came into the national spotlight this year in other ways, too.)

River love

Portlanders gathered at the Willamette River en masse this summer, with weekly river parties demonstrating how excited people are to embrace a clean, swimmable river. After a hot stretch, the river saw a toxic algae bloom, making it briefly unsafe for summer frolicking—the climate crisis in action, folks. Luckily, a summer rainstorm disrupted the algae bloom, but advocates continue to emphasize the need to take action to mitigate the effects of climate change on Portland’s river.

PCEF continues funding climate action (even as Trump seeks to destroy the earth)

The Trump administration has done serious damage to climate action since taking office at the beginning of the year. Between clawing back funds for clean energy projects, firing federal climate researchers, and installing climate change deniers throughout every sector of government, these lunatics are really doing everything to hasten humanity’s demise. It won’t be enough to solve everything, but Portland’s clean energy fund offers a potential roadmap for taking action in the age of Trump. The Portland Clean Energy Community Benefits Fund (PCEF) just allocated more than $60 million toward dozens of local climate projects, ranging from electric bike incentives to energy-efficient home retrofits.

2026 will be another big year for local climate news. Stay tuned to the Mercury for more.

name: EVs
title: Solar Technology and Data Centres Fuel Silver Demand in 2025 - Discovery Alert
description:
From representing 11% of industrial silver consumption in 2014, solar applications now account for 29% of total demand, creating the largest single driver of industrial silver consumption globally.
According to Silver Institute research, "silver demand is forecast to expand across key technology sectors, with solar photovoltaics leading industrial consumption growth through 2030."
Investment Implications: Portfolio Positioning for Silver Demand Growth The convergence of solar EVs data centers drive silver demand creates diverse investment opportunities across mining equities, technology sector exposure, and direct commodity investment.
Technology Sector Correlation: Silver-Dependent Industries Performance Technology sector investments in solar, electric vehicle, and data center industries provide indirect silver exposure while benefiting from end-market demand growth.
Technology Substitution Threats: Alternative Materials Development Research into alternative conductive materials poses the most significant long-term threat to silver demand growth.
text:
How Will Three Technological Megatrends Reshape Silver Markets by 2030?

The convergence of renewable energy deployment, transportation electrification, and digital infrastructure expansion represents the most significant industrial transformation since the advent of mass manufacturing. As solar EVs data centers drive silver demand through unprecedented technological adoption rates, these three megatrends operate independently yet create multiplicative demand pressures on critical materials, with silver positioned at the intersection of all three technological revolutions.

The Convergence of Energy Transition, Electrification, and Digital Infrastructure

Global renewable energy capacity is projected to expand by 2,700 GW between 2024-2029, with solar and wind technologies accounting for approximately 90% of this unprecedented growth. This expansion coincides with transportation electrification accelerating beyond traditional forecasts, as electric vehicle adoption curves steepen across major markets. Simultaneously, artificial intelligence workloads are driving data center construction at rates exceeding 50% per decade in key regions.

The simultaneity of these trends creates what analysts describe as overlapping demand acceleration. Unlike previous commodity cycles driven by single-sector expansion, the 2025-2030 period features synchronized growth across three independent demand drivers, each requiring silver-intensive manufacturing processes and infrastructure components.

Furthermore, the silver market squeeze demonstrates how supply constraints amplify price volatility during periods of accelerated industrial consumption.

Strategic Scenario Framework for Silver Demand Analysis

Strategic scenario modelling reveals three distinct pathways for silver demand evolution through 2030:

• Base Case Scenario: Moderate policy continuity with existing renewable energy targets maintained, EV adoption following current market trajectories reaching 50% of new vehicle sales by 2030 in developed markets, and data center expansion aligned with AI deployment forecasts

• Accelerated Scenario: Enhanced policy support for renewable energy, accelerated EV adoption exceeding 60% market share by 2030, and rapid AI workload migration to cloud infrastructure

• Constrained Scenario: Policy reversals, subsidy elimination, supply chain disruptions, and technology substitution pressures reducing silver demand growth rates by 30-40%

Each scenario incorporates distinct geographic distribution patterns, regulatory environments, and technological adoption rates that influence silver consumption across industrial applications. Moreover, effective silver squeeze strategies can help investors navigate these varying market conditions.

Market Structure Transformation Timeline

The transformation timeline reveals critical inflection points across all three megatrends. Solar photovoltaic installations are projected to reach 1,735 GW global capacity by 2028, representing a 13% compound annual growth rate. Electric vehicle production is expected to transition from current levels of 12 million units annually to 35 million units by 2031. Data center electricity consumption approaches 1,000 TWh annually by 2026, representing 3-5% of global electricity demand.

These inflection points create temporal clustering of silver demand acceleration, with peak consumption periods potentially coinciding across sectors during 2027-2029, generating supply-demand imbalances that traditional mining production cycles may struggle to accommodate. Additionally, comprehensive precious metals analysis indicates broader market dynamics affecting silver valuations.

What Makes Silver the Critical Metal for Next-Generation Technologies?

Silver's position as the premier electrical conductor among all metals creates an irreplaceable foundation for next-generation technological applications. With electrical conductivity of 63.0 MS/m and thermal conductivity of 429 W/m·K, silver outperforms all alternative materials in scenarios where energy efficiency and thermal management determine system performance and longevity.

Electrical Conductivity Requirements in Advanced Applications

The superiority of silver in electrical applications stems from its atomic structure, which provides minimal resistance to electron flow. Silver exhibits 5.8% higher electrical conductivity than copper and 39.4% higher thermal conductivity than gold, creating measurable performance advantages in high-current and high-frequency applications.

In solar photovoltaic systems, even marginal resistance increases reduce cell efficiency by 0.1-0.2% per unit of resistance increase. This sensitivity makes silver's conductivity premium economically justifiable despite cost differentials. Modern photovoltaic cells incorporate sophisticated contact architectures utilising 85-95% silver content pastes, applied through precision screen printing and sintered at 750-850°C to achieve optimal conductivity characteristics.

Electric vehicle battery management systems operate at 400-800 volts with peak currents exceeding 500 amperes, necessitating ultra-low-resistance connections where silver's conductivity provides measurable safety and efficiency advantages. Tesla's Model 3 and Model Y battery architectures specifically incorporate silver-based connectors to manage charging currents exceeding 200 amperes while maintaining voltage losses below 50 millivolts.

Thermal Management Properties for High-Performance Systems

Silver's thermal conductivity properties become particularly critical in high-density computing environments where server processors operate at 200+ watts per unit. Silver-based thermal interface materials and solder formulations provide superior heat dissipation compared to copper-based alternatives, directly enabling higher processing speeds and reduced cooling requirements.

The relationship between thermal management and system performance creates a direct correlation between silver content and computational capability. Data centers utilising silver-enhanced thermal management systems achieve 15-20% improvements in processing density while reducing cooling energy consumption by similar margins.

Industrial Substitution Challenges and Cost-Benefit Analysis

Despite silver's cost premium, substitution barriers remain substantial across critical applications. Alternative materials face fundamental limitations:

• Copper: 5.8% lower electrical conductivity, higher corrosion susceptibility, increased thickness requirements

• Gold: Superior corrosion resistance but 39.4% lower thermal conductivity, significantly higher cost per unit

• Aluminium: 40% lower electrical conductivity, structural integrity limitations in high-current applications

• Graphene-based conductors: Promising theoretical properties but manufacturing scalability challenges and cost uncertainties

The cost-performance analysis reveals silver justification thresholds where efficiency gains exceed material cost premiums. In solar applications, silver represents 8-10% of total module cost despite comprising only 0.05-0.08% of module mass, demonstrating performance-driven value creation.

Table: Silver's Technical Properties vs. Alternative Conductors

Property Silver Copper Gold Aluminium Electrical Conductivity (MS/m) 63.0 59.6 45.2 37.8 Thermal Conductivity (W/m·K) 429 401 318 237 Corrosion Resistance High Medium Highest Low Cost per kg (USD) $800-900 $9-10 $65,000 $2-3

Solar Photovoltaic Sector: The Primary Industrial Demand Driver

The solar photovoltaic sector's evolution represents the most dramatic shift in silver demand patterns over the past decade. From representing 11% of industrial silver consumption in 2014, solar applications now account for 29% of total demand, creating the largest single driver of industrial silver consumption globally.

Evolution of Silver Consumption in PV Technology (2014-2024)

The transformation of silver usage in photovoltaic technology reflects competing forces: technological advancement reducing per-unit consumption while installation volume growth drives total demand acceleration. Silver content per photovoltaic cell decreased from 521 mg in 2014 to 111 mg in 2024, representing a 78.7% reduction over the decade.

This reduction resulted from three distinct technological pathways:

• Geometry Optimisation: Advanced computer modelling improved contact finger spacing and width, reducing silver usage by approximately 30% while maintaining electrical performance

• Silver Paste Innovation: Next-generation nanopastes and composite materials require 25-35% less silver by volume to achieve equivalent conductivity through nanostructure architecture

• Contact Design Evolution: Transition from simple grid structures to sophisticated designs including selective emitters and split busbars, improving current collection efficiency with narrower conductors

Technological Efficiency Gains vs. Installation Volume Growth

Despite remarkable per-unit silver reduction, total silver consumption continues accelerating due to installation volume growth rates exceeding technological reduction rates. The mathematical relationship demonstrates this dynamic:

Total Silver Demand = Installation Volume × Silver Content per Unit

When installation growth of 20-27% compound annual growth rate exceeds technical reduction rates of approximately 3-4% annually, total demand accelerates despite per-unit efficiency improvements. This creates a structural demand floor that cannot be significantly reduced through further miniaturisation without compromising electrical performance.

Regional Solar Capacity Expansion Scenarios Through 2030

Global solar deployment targets reveal the scale of upcoming installation requirements across major markets:

• European Union: 260 GW (2025) targeting 700 GW (2030) representing 169% expansion

• United States: 180 GW (2025) targeting 450 GW (2030) representing 150% growth

• China: 420 GW (2025) targeting 1,200 GW (2030) representing 186% expansion

• India: 85 GW (2025) targeting 280 GW (2030) representing 229% growth

These targets translate into compound annual growth rates ranging from 20.1% to 26.9% across major markets, creating unprecedented demand for silver-intensive photovoltaic modules. According to Silver Institute research, "silver demand is forecast to expand across key technology sectors, with solar photovoltaics leading industrial consumption growth through 2030."

Policy Impact Analysis: US Federal Subsidy Elimination vs. State-Level Incentives

The elimination of federal green energy subsidies through executive order in July 2025 created significant policy uncertainty for US solar deployment. However, analysis indicates continued growth supported by state-level incentives and high electricity demand from expanding data center operations.

State-level renewable portfolio standards continue supporting deployment across major markets:

• California: State mandates 100% carbon-free electricity by 2045

• Texas: Renewable energy targets supported by ERCOT grid planning requirements

• New York: Climate Leadership and Community Protection Act mandates 85% emissions reduction by 2040

• Virginia: Clean Economy Act mandates 100% carbon-free electricity by 2045

These programmes, combined with electricity demand growth from data center expansion, support continued 14% compound annual growth rate for US solar deployment through 2030, despite federal policy changes.

Trade War Implications: Tariff Impact on PV Production Costs and Demand

Current tariff structures create significant cost pressures on solar deployment while potentially altering global supply chain patterns:

• US tariffs on Chinese solar modules: 50-60% (implemented 2024-2025)

• EU anti-dumping duties on Chinese PV cells: 17.5% base rate plus additional provisional duties

• Manufacturing reshoring initiatives: Policy support for domestic solar manufacturing capacity

These trade measures increase installed costs by 15-25% in affected markets but may accelerate silver demand in regions developing domestic manufacturing capabilities, as production localisation typically increases material usage during initial scaling phases.

Electric Vehicle Revolution: Automotive Silver Consumption Transformation

The transition from internal combustion engines to electric powertrains represents a fundamental shift in automotive silver consumption patterns. Electric vehicles require 25-50 grams of silver per unit compared to traditional vehicles, representing a 100-150% increase in automotive silver consumption per vehicle.

EV vs. Internal Combustion Engine Silver Requirements Analysis

The silver content difference between electric and internal combustion vehicles stems from distinct system architectures and performance requirements:

Internal Combustion Engine Vehicles (15-25 grams silver per vehicle):

• Electrical system components: alternator, starter motor, ignition systems

• Electronic control units: engine management, emissions control systems

• Comfort and convenience features: infotainment, climate control, safety systems

Electric Vehicles (25-50 grams silver per vehicle):

• Battery management systems: cell monitoring, thermal management, safety systems

• Power electronics: inverters, DC-DC converters, onboard chargers

• Motor control systems: traction motor controllers, regenerative braking systems

• Enhanced electrical architecture: high-voltage wiring, contactors, fusing systems

Battery Technology Evolution and Silver Integration Patterns

Modern electric vehicle battery systems operate at voltages ranging from 400V to 800V with current demands exceeding 500 amperes during peak charging and acceleration events. Silver integration occurs at multiple system levels:

Cell-Level Integration:

• Current collectors and tab connections utilising silver-copper composite materials

• Thermal management sensors requiring silver-based temperature monitoring systems

• Safety disconnect mechanisms incorporating silver-plated contactors

Module-Level Integration:

• Busbar connections between cell groups using silver-enhanced conductive materials

• Voltage monitoring circuits requiring precision silver-based sensing components

• Cooling system interfaces utilising silver thermal interface materials

Pack-Level Integration:

• High-current main contactors with silver-based switching elements

• Fusing systems utilising silver-enhanced protective devices

• Charging port connections requiring silver-plated contact surfaces

Charging Infrastructure Buildout: The Hidden Silver Demand Driver

The expansion of electric vehicle charging infrastructure creates additional silver demand beyond vehicle production. Fast-charging stations require substantial silver content in power conversion equipment, contactors, and switching systems.

DC Fast Charging Station Silver Requirements:

• Level 2 Chargers (7-22 kW): 50-100 grams silver per unit

• DC Fast Chargers (50-150 kW): 200-400 grams silver per unit

• Ultra-Fast Chargers (350+ kW): 500-800 grams silver per unit

Current deployment targets suggest installation of 500,000+ charging stations globally by 2030, creating cumulative silver demand of 100-200 million ounces for charging infrastructure alone.

Market Penetration Scenarios: EV Adoption Curves by Geographic Region

Electric vehicle adoption demonstrates significant regional variation driven by policy support, charging infrastructure availability, and consumer preferences:

• Europe: 60%+ EV market share targeted by 2030, supported by emission regulations and purchase incentives

• China: 50%+ EV market share projected by 2030, driven by domestic manufacturing capacity and urban air quality requirements

• United States: 40-50% EV market share projected by 2030, supported by state-level mandates and federal infrastructure investment

• Emerging Markets: 20-30% EV market share by 2030, constrained by charging infrastructure and vehicle affordability

Table: Automotive Silver Demand Transformation (2025-2031)

Vehicle Type Silver Content (grams) 2025 Production (millions) 2031 Projection (millions) Total Silver Demand (ounces) ICE Vehicles 15-25 75 45 24-40 million Hybrid Vehicles 18-34 8 15 4-8 million Battery EVs 25-50 12 35 28-56 million

Solid-State Battery Technology: The Next Silver Demand Multiplier

Emerging solid-state battery technology promises enhanced energy density and safety characteristics while potentially increasing silver requirements per vehicle. Solid-state systems require more sophisticated thermal management and electrical monitoring systems, potentially increasing silver content to 60-80 grams per vehicle.

Major automotive manufacturers including Toyota, BMW, and Stellantis have announced solid-state battery commercialisation timelines between 2027-2030, suggesting potential silver demand multiplication beyond current projections if this technology achieves widespread adoption.

Data Center Expansion: AI and Cloud Computing Silver Requirements

The global data center industry has undergone remarkable transformation over the past two decades, with facilities increasing from approximately 400 in 2000 to over 4,600 in 2025. More significantly, total global IT power capacity expanded by approximately 5,252%, growing from 0.93GW in 2000 to nearly 50GW in 2025.

Global Computing Infrastructure Growth Patterns (2000-2025)

The evolution of data center infrastructure reflects fundamental shifts in computing architecture, performance requirements, and geographic distribution. Early facilities focused on basic server hosting and storage, while modern hyperscale data centers support complex artificial intelligence workloads requiring specialised hardware configurations.

Data Center Growth Metrics:

• Facility Count: 11x increase from 400 to 4,600+ facilities globally

• Power Capacity: 53x expansion from 0.93GW to 50GW

• Power Density: Average rack density increased from 2-4 kW per rack (2000) to 15-25 kW per rack (2025)

• Geographic Expansion: Initially concentrated in North America and Western Europe, now distributed across all continents

Power Capacity Expansion: From 0.93GW to 50GW Analysis

The dramatic expansion in data center power capacity reflects both facility multiplication and individual facility scale increases. Modern hyperscale data centers operate at power levels exceeding 100MW, compared to early facilities typically consuming 1-5MW.

This power capacity growth directly correlates with silver demand through several mechanisms:

• Server Hardware: Each server contains 15-25 grams of silver in processors, memory modules, and connectivity components

• Network Infrastructure: Switches, routers, and optical equipment utilise silver in high-speed connectors and thermal management systems

• Power Distribution: Uninterruptible power supplies, transformers, and electrical distribution systems require silver-enhanced components

• Cooling Systems: Precision air conditioning and liquid cooling systems incorporate silver-based heat exchangers and sensors

Geographic Distribution Shifts: Emerging Market Data Center Construction

Current data center capacity concentration reflects historical technology adoption patterns, with North America, Western Europe, and East/Southeast Asia accounting for 88% of global computing capacity. However, expansion into emerging markets accelerates as latency-sensitive applications require proximity to end-users.

Regional Capacity Distribution:

• North America: 25.5GW capacity (51% global share), led by United States with 22.57GW

• Western Europe: 8.2GW capacity (16.4% global share), concentrated in Netherlands, Germany, and United Kingdom

• East/Southeast Asia: 10.3GW capacity (20.6% global share), dominated by China, Japan, and Singapore

• Emerging Markets: 6.0GW capacity (12% global share), rapidly expanding in Latin America, South Asia, and Africa

AI Workload Requirements: High-Performance Computing Silver Intensity

Artificial intelligence workloads create unprecedented demands on computing infrastructure, requiring specialised processors, high-speed memory systems, and advanced cooling solutions. AI-optimised servers contain 40-60% more silver per unit compared to traditional servers due to enhanced thermal management requirements and higher-density component integration.

AI Hardware Silver Content:

• GPU Accelerators: 8-12 grams silver per unit for thermal interface materials and high-speed connectors

• High-Bandwidth Memory: 2-4 grams silver per memory module for signal integrity and thermal management

• Networking Components: 5-8 grams silver per switch port for 100+ gigabit ethernet connectivity

• Power Delivery Systems: 10-15 grams silver per server for enhanced power conversion efficiency

Edge Computing Deployment: Latency-Sensitive Applications in New Markets

Edge computing deployment drives data center construction into previously underserved markets, creating distributed silver demand patterns. Edge facilities, while smaller than hyperscale centers, require proportionally higher silver content per unit of computing capacity due to less efficient cooling and power distribution systems.

Projected edge computing expansion suggests 5,000+ new edge facilities globally by 2030, concentrated in emerging markets including Latin America, Southeast Asia, and Africa. These facilities will collectively consume 50-75 million ounces of silver through 2030.

Consequently, the critical minerals energy transition demonstrates how digital infrastructure expansion intersects with broader resource security considerations.

Table: Regional Data Center Capacity Distribution and Silver Demand

Region Current Capacity (GW) Market Share Growth Projection Silver Demand Impact North America 25.5 51% High Very High Western Europe 8.2 16.4% Medium High East/Southeast Asia 10.3 20.6% Very High Very High Emerging Markets 6.0 12% Extreme Medium-High

Supply-Demand Dynamics: Market Tension Points Through 2030

Global industrial silver demand reached 680.5 million ounces in 2024, with solar EVs data centers drive silver demand representing the dominant growth vectors across technology sectors. This demand level approaches historical production capacity limits, creating potential supply-demand imbalances as the three technological megatrends accelerate through 2030.

Industrial Demand Growth vs. Mining Production Capacity

Primary silver mine production averaged 830-850 million ounces annually over the past five years, with approximately 200 million ounces derived from recycling and secondary sources. Total available supply of 1,050 million ounces accommodates current industrial demand of 680.5 million ounces plus investment demand and monetary applications.

However, projected industrial demand growth creates concerning supply adequacy scenarios:

• 2025 Projected Industrial Demand: 720-750 million ounces

• 2027 Projected Industrial Demand: 820-880 million ounces

• 2030 Projected Industrial Demand: 950-1,050 million ounces

These projections suggest industrial demand alone could consume 90-100% of total silver supply by 2030, leaving minimal inventory for investment demand, monetary applications, and supply chain buffer stocks.

Inventory Drawdown Patterns and Strategic Reserve Analysis

Exchange-traded fund holdings and institutional inventories provide supply chain flexibility during demand surges. Current inventory levels include:

• COMEX Warehouse Stocks: 280-320 million ounces (varies seasonally)

• London Bullion Market: 150-200 million ounces in allocated storage

• ETF Holdings: 950+ million ounces in physically-backed exchange-traded funds

• Industrial Strategic Reserves: 200-300 million ounces held by major manufacturers

Historical analysis indicates inventory drawdowns of 100-150 million ounces during supply-demand imbalances, suggesting available buffer capacity of 400-500 million ounces. However, this inventory represents approximately 6-8 months of global industrial consumption, providing limited cushion for extended supply disruptions.

Price Discovery Mechanisms in Constrained Supply Scenarios

Silver pricing mechanisms historically demonstrate high elasticity to supply-demand imbalances due to the metal's dual role as industrial commodity and monetary store of value. Supply constraints typically generate price responses that reduce industrial demand through substitution while attracting additional mining investment.

Price Response Scenarios:

• Moderate Supply Constraint: Silver prices $35-45/ounce, reducing demand by 5-10% through efficiency improvements and limited substitution

• Significant Supply Constraint: Silver prices $45-60/ounce, reducing demand by 10-20% through accelerated substitution research and alternative materials adoption

• Severe Supply Constraint: Silver prices $60+/ounce, potentially reducing demand by 20-30% through widespread substitution and technological alternatives

As reported by AI Invest, "silver serves as an overlooked catalyst for the technology and green energy transition, with price appreciation potential to $60/ounce by late 2026."

Recycling and Secondary Supply: Urban Mining Potential Assessment

Silver recycling currently provides approximately 200 million ounces annually, primarily from jewellery, photography, and electronics. However, solar panels installed over the past decade will begin reaching end-of-life status around 2035-2040, potentially providing substantial recycling feedstock.

Recycling Potential by Source:

• Solar Panels: 300-500 million ounces recoverable from installations through 2030 (available 2040+)

• Electronic Waste: 100-150 million ounces annually from smartphones, computers, and consumer electronics

• Automotive Components: 50-75 million ounces annually from end-of-life vehicle processing

• Industrial Equipment: 75-100 million ounces annually from data center hardware and manufacturing equipment

Enhanced recycling could provide 400-600 million ounces annually by 2035, significantly alleviating supply constraints if collection and processing infrastructure develops adequately.

Investment Implications: Portfolio Positioning for Silver Demand Growth

The convergence of solar EVs data centers drive silver demand creates diverse investment opportunities across mining equities, technology sector exposure, and direct commodity investment. Portfolio positioning strategies must consider both the industrial demand growth narrative and supply-demand timing dynamics.

Mining Equity Exposure: Major Silver Producers Analysis

Primary silver mining companies and silver-producing base metal miners offer direct exposure to demand growth and price appreciation scenarios. Key considerations include:

Pure Silver Producers:

• Production capacity expansion potential to meet growing demand

• Geographic diversification across stable mining jurisdictions

• Cost structure positioning for various silver price scenarios

• Resource quality and reserve longevity relative to demand projections

Polymetallic Miners:

• Copper-silver producers benefit from dual exposure to electrification trends

• Lead-zinc-silver miners provide geographic and commodity diversification

• Gold-silver producers offer precious metals complex exposure

Mining equity valuations typically respond to silver price movements with 2-3x leverage, providing amplified returns during commodity price appreciation cycles while creating corresponding downside risks during price corrections. Furthermore, the Coeur Mining transformation exemplifies how established miners adapt to evolving market dynamics.

Technology Sector Correlation: Silver-Dependent Industries Performance

Technology sector investments in solar, electric vehicle, and data center industries provide indirect silver exposure while benefiting from end-market demand growth. This correlation creates portfolio diversification opportunities and sector rotation strategies.

Solar Industry Exposure:

• Module manufacturers with vertically integrated supply chains

• Installation and development companies in high-growth markets

• Inverter and balance-of-system component suppliers

Electric Vehicle Ecosystem:

• Battery manufacturers with advanced chemistry capabilities

• Power electronics and charging infrastructure providers

• Automotive manufacturers with strong EV product pipelines

Data Center Infrastructure:

• REITs specialising in data center properties and development

• Server and networking equipment manufacturers

• Cloud service providers with capacity expansion plans

Commodity ETF and Physical Silver Investment Considerations

Direct silver exposure through exchange-traded funds and physical ownership provides pure commodity exposure without company-specific risks. Investment vehicle selection depends on storage preferences, tax considerations, and liquidity requirements.

Physically-Backed ETFs:

• iShares Silver Trust (SLV): Largest silver ETF with high liquidity

• Aberdeen Standard Physical Silver Shares ETF (SIVR): Lower expense ratios

• Sprott Physical Silver Trust (PSLV): Canadian structure with potential premium/discount dynamics

Physical Silver Ownership:

• Coins and bars for direct ownership and storage control

• Allocated storage through precious metals dealers

• Pool accounts and certificate programmes for larger positions

Physical ownership eliminates counterparty risks while creating storage costs and insurance considerations. Tax implications vary by jurisdiction and investment structure.

Table: Silver Demand Growth Rates by Sector (2025-2030)

Sector Current Demand (Moz) 2030 Projection (Moz) CAGR Risk Factors Solar PV 200 250 4.6% Technology substitution Automotive 65 95 7.9% EV adoption rates Electronics 180 220 4.1% Miniaturisation trends Data Centers 25 45 12.4% AI deployment speed

Risk Assessment: Potential Demand Disruption Scenarios

While the convergence of solar, EVs, and data centers appears to create robust silver demand growth, several risk factors could disrupt these projections. Understanding these scenarios enables more informed investment positioning and risk management strategies.

Technology Substitution Threats: Alternative Materials Development

Research into alternative conductive materials poses the most significant long-term threat to silver demand growth. Several technologies show promise for specific applications:

Graphene-Based Conductors:

• Theoretical electrical conductivity exceeding silver by 15-20%

• Manufacturing scalability challenges remain unresolved

• Cost competitiveness timeline uncertain, estimated 2030+ for commercial viability

Copper Nanostructures:

• Enhanced conductivity through nanostructure engineering

• Lower material costs but higher processing complexity

• Limited applicability to high-temperature environments

Advanced Aluminium Alloys:

• Weight advantages in automotive and aerospace applications

• Electrical conductivity 40% lower than silver, requiring design modifications

• Cost advantages significant but performance trade-offs substantial

Policy Reversal Impact: Green Energy Subsidy Changes

The elimination of federal green energy subsidies in July 2025 demonstrates how policy changes can impact demand projections. Additional policy risks include:

Renewable Energy Mandates:

• State and national renewable portfolio standards subject to political changes

• Grid integration costs potentially reducing solar deployment economics

• Trade policies affecting international supply chain competitiveness

Electric Vehicle Incentives:

• Purchase tax credits and rebate programmes vulnerable to budget constraints

• Charging infrastructure funding dependent on government support

• Emission regulations driving EV adoption may face industry opposition

Data Center Energy Policies:

• Carbon taxes and emission regulations affecting data center operations

• Energy efficiency mandates potentially reducing power consumption growth

• Cryptocurrency mining restrictions impacting specialised data center demand

Economic Recession Scenarios: Industrial Demand Sensitivity Analysis

Economic downturns historically reduce industrial silver demand through delayed capital investments and production reductions. Recession impact varies by sector:

Solar Deployment Sensitivity:

• Commercial and utility-scale projects dependent on financing availability

• Residential installations sensitive to consumer discretionary spending

• Government support programmes vulnerable to budget pressures during recessions

Electric Vehicle Adoption:

• High vehicle prices make EVs sensitive to economic uncertainty

• Credit availability affects consumer financing options

• Commercial fleet electrification may be delayed during cost-cutting cycles

Data Center Construction:

• Enterprise IT spending reductions during economic uncertainty

• Cloud service adoption may decelerate during budget constraints

• AI investment cycles vulnerable to technology sector downturns

The intersection of these risk factors with solar EVs data centers drive silver demand creates complex scenarios requiring careful analysis and diversified positioning strategies to manage potential volatility while capturing long-term growth opportunities.

Ready to Capitalise on the Silver Technology Revolution?
